sen.j: 石橋氏（いしばしし）は日本の武家の姓のひとつ。
sen.e: The Ishibashi clan is a samurai family name in Japan.
The Ishibashi clan is the name of a samurai family in Japan.
The Ishibashi clan is the name of a samurai family in Japan.

sen.j: 甲斐国､美濃国､下野国､三河国､尾張国､相模国､武蔵国､常陸国等に石橋村がありこれ等より起こる。
sen.e: There were Ishibashi-mura villages in Provinces such as Kai, Mino, Shinotsuke, Mikawa, Owari, Sagami, Musashi and Hitachi; where the name is derived from.
The clan derived from Ishibashi-mura villages in various Provinces including Kai, Mino, Shimotsuke, Mikawa, Owari, Sagami, Musashi, Hitachi.
The clan derived from Ishibashi-mura villages in various Provinces including Kai, Mino, Shimotsuke, Mikawa, Owari, Sagami, Musashi, Hitachi.

sen.j: 源氏姓の石橋氏が最も有名である。
sen.e: The most famous Ishibashi clans are the lineage of the Minamoto clan (Genji).
The Ishibashi clan of Genji (the Minamoto clan) is the most famous.
The Ishibashi clan of Genji (the Minamoto clan) is the most famous.

sen.j: 現在千葉県､島根県､福岡県等に多い
sen.e: Today, many live in Chiba, Shimane and Fukuoka Prefectures.
Today, many of the descendents live in Chiba, Shimane and Fukuoka Prefectures.
sen.cmt: 直前の文言を受けて、「子孫の多くは・・・」としました。
sen.e: Today, many of the descendents live in Chiba, Shimane and Fukuoka Prefectures.

sen.j: 清和源氏武田氏流 甲斐国八代郡小石和筋石橋村より起こる。
sen.e: The lineage derived from the Takeda clan of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa): originated from Ishibashi-mura village in Koisawasuji, Yatsushiro District and Kai Province.
The Takeda clan line of Seiwa Genji (Minamoto clan originated from the Emperor Seiwa): Originated in Ishibashi-mura Village, Koisawasuji, Yatsushiro County, Kai Province
The Takeda clan line of Seiwa Genji (Minamoto clan originated from the Emperor Seiwa): Originated in Ishibashi-mura Village, Koisawasuji, Yatsushiro County, Kai Province

sen.j: → 石橋氏 (甲斐国)
sen.e: -> Ishibashi clan (Kai Province)
-> Ishibashi clan (Kai Province)
-> Ishibashi clan (Kai Province)

sen.j: 清和源氏足利氏流 以下で解説する。
sen.e: The lineage derived from Ashikaga clan of Seiwa-Genji: see below.
The Ashikaga clan of Seiwa Genji: To be explained below.
The Ashikaga clan of Seiwa Genji: To be explained below.

sen.j: 清和源氏源義綱流 美濃国石橋より起こる。
sen.e: The lineage derived from MINAMOTO no Yoshitsuna of Seiwa-Genji: originated from the Ishibashi, Mino Province.
MINAMOTO no Yoshitsuna line of Seiwa-Genji: Originated in Ishibashi, Mino Province.
MINAMOTO no Yoshitsuna line of Seiwa-Genji: Originated in Ishibashi, Mino Province.

sen.j: 義綱の子の源義仲 (曖昧さ回避)を祖とする。
sen.e: One of them had Yoshitsuna's son MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka (曖昧さ回避) as the founder.
sen.cmt: (曖昧さ回避)の意味が分かりませんでした。
sen.e: Originated from MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, Yoshitsuna's son.
sen.cmt: 「曖昧さ回避」は本文とは関係ないので、無視しました。
sen.e: Originated from MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, Yoshitsuna's son.

sen.j: → 石橋氏 (美濃国)
sen.e: -> Ishibashi clan (Mino Province)
-> The Ishibashi clan (Mino Province)
-> The Ishibashi clan (Mino Province)

sen.j: また、義綱の七男の源義直を祖とする。
sen.e: The other lineage had Yoshitsuna's seventh son MINAMOTO no Yoshinao as the founder.
Originated from MINAMOTO no Yoshinao, Yoshitsuna's seventh son.
Originated from MINAMOTO no Yoshinao, Yoshitsuna's seventh son.

sen.j: → 石橋氏 (河内国)
sen.e: -> Ishibashi clan (Kawachi Province)
-> The Ishibashi clan (Kawachi Province)
-> The Ishibashi clan (Kawachi Province)

sen.j: 宇多源氏佐々木氏流 真野氏真野定時の子の石橋定範を祖とする。
sen.e: The lineage derived from the Sasaki clan of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Uda): had Sadanori ISHIBASHI, a son of Sadatoki MANO of the Mano clan's the founder.
sen.cmt: 「真野定時」、「石橋定範」は読みが不明です。
sen.e: The Sasaki clan line of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Uda): Originated from Sadanori ISHIBASHI, a son of Sadatoki MANO.
The Sasaki clan line of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Uda): Originated from Sadanori ISHIBASHI, a son of Sadatoki MANO.

sen.j: → 石橋氏 (佐々木氏)
sen.e: -> Ishibashi clan (Sasaki clan)
-> The Ishibashi clan (Sasaki clan)
-> The Ishibashi clan (Sasaki clan)

tit.e: The Origin of the Family Name
The Origin of the Family Name
The Origin of the Family Name

sen.j: 石橋の名を地名に由来するのもだとすると、『姓氏家系大辞典』等では、下野国石橋が和義の名字のもととなったと想定しているが、鎌倉期の足利家領三河国設楽郡内にも石橋の地名があるし、京都市中にも石橋の地名があり、全国各地に石の橋に因んで存在し、未だに由来が判然としない。
sen.e: Assuming that the name Ishibashi is derived from the name of a place, in the records such as "Seishi Kakei Daijiten" (a large dictionary of Japanese surnames) says that the Ishibashi of Shimotsuke Province was the origin of the family name of Kazuyoshi (or Masayoshi), but there was a place called Ishibashi in the Shitara District, Mikawa Province, a territory of the Ashikaga clan in the Kamakura period and another Ishibashi in Kyoto; the clan exist in various regions where a stone bridge (Ishibashi literally means 'Stone Bridge') was, so the origin is not yet clear.

Assuming that the name Ishibashi is derived from the name of a place, some writings including "Seishi Kakei Daijiten" (a large dictionary of Japanese surnames) state that Kazuyoshi (or Masayoshi) Ishibashi adopted his surname from a place called Ishibashi, Shimotsuke Province, but the origin of the name Ishibashi is unclear because there are many places called Ishibashi; in addition to Ishibashi in Shitara County in Mikawa Province, the Ashikaga clan's territory in the Kamakura period, or another Ishibashi in Kyoto, there are the places which were named after a stone bridge (Ishibashi literally means 'Stone Bridge') throughout Japan.

Assuming that the name Ishibashi is derived from the name of a place, some writings including "Seishi Kakei Daijiten" (a large dictionary of Japanese surnames) state that Kazuyoshi (or Masayoshi) Ishibashi adopted his surname from a place called Ishibashi, Shimotsuke Province, but the origin of the name Ishibashi is unclear because there are many places called Ishibashi; in addition to Ishibashi in Shitara County in Mikawa Province, the Ashikaga clan's territory in the Kamakura period, or another Ishibashi in Kyoto, there are the places which were named after a stone bridge (Ishibashi literally means 'Stone Bridge') throughout Japan.

sen.j: 何れにしても、石橋氏の呼称は足利直義派宿老及び評定衆の筆頭にまで上り詰めたため、一家として名を表すことが必要だった事によるものであると考えられる。
sen.e: Anyway, it is thought that, when this family became Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA's shukuro (chief vassals) and hyojoshu (members of council of state), they needed to have a name to show as a family.
It is possible that the clan, which was promoted to Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA's shukuro (chief vassal) and hyojoshu (members of council of state), needed a name as a clan.
It is possible that the clan, which was promoted to Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA's shukuro (chief vassal) and hyojoshu (members of council of state), needed a name as a clan.

tit.e: The Lineage from the Ashikaga clan of the Minamoto Family
The Ashikaga clan of the Minamoto family
The Ashikaga clan of the Minamoto family

sen.j: 足利泰氏の庶長子足利家氏の子義利は上野国広沢郷を伝領し、広沢義利と名乗った。
sen.e: Yoshitoshi, the son of Yasuuji ASHIKAGA's eldest child born out of wedlock Ieuji ASHIKAGA, inherited Hirosawa-go, Kozuke Province and changed his name to Yoshitoshi HIROSAWA.
Yoshitoshi ASHIKAGA, a son of Ieuji ASHIKAGA who was the illegitimate eldest son of Yasuuji ASHIKAGA, inherited Hirosawa-go, Kozuke Province and changed his name to Yoshitoshi HIROSAWA.
Yoshitoshi ASHIKAGA, a son of Ieuji ASHIKAGA who was the illegitimate eldest son of Yasuuji ASHIKAGA, inherited Hirosawa-go, Kozuke Province and changed his name to Yoshitoshi HIROSAWA.

sen.j: その子は三河国吉田郷に移り住み、吉田義博と名乗る。
sen.e: His son moved to Yoshida-go, Mikawa Province and named himself Yoshihiro YOSHIDA.
His son moved to Yoshida-go, Mikawa Province and gave his name as Yoshihiro YOSHIDA.
His son moved to Yoshida-go, Mikawa Province and gave his name as Yoshihiro YOSHIDA.

sen.j: その子は石橋和義を名乗る。
sen.e: Then his son named himself Kazuyoshi ISHIBASHI.
Yoshihiro's son gave his name as Kazuyoshi ISHIBASHI.
Yoshihiro's son gave his name as Kazuyoshi ISHIBASHI.

sen.j: 和義は宗家である斯波高経の下、足利尊氏に従い、尊氏西走の時、備前国三石城の守備を任された。
sen.e: Kazuyoshi followed Takauji ASHIKAGA with the head of family Takatsune SHIBA and when Takauji escaped to Saigoku (western part of Japan), he was appointed as a guard of the Mitsuishi-jo Castle of the Bizen Province.

Kazuyoshi followed Takauji ASHIKAGA with Takatsune SHIBA of head family of the Ishibashi family and when Takauji escaped to Saigoku (western part of Japan), he was appointed as a guard of the Mitsuishi-jo Castle of the Bizen Province.
sen.cmt: 「宗家である・・・」は「石橋家の宗家」としました。
sen.e: Kazuyoshi followed Takauji ASHIKAGA with Takatsune SHIBA of head family of the Ishibashi family and when Takauji escaped to Saigoku (western part of Japan), he was appointed as a guard of the Mitsuishi-jo Castle of the Bizen Province.

sen.j: 和義は脇屋義助に包囲されながらも城を守りきり、戦功を上げた。
sen.e: Although he was besieged by Yoshisuke WAKIYA, he protected the castle and did a great war service.
He was credited with protecting the castle against Yoshisuke WAKIYA.
He was credited with protecting the castle against Yoshisuke WAKIYA.

sen.j: これにより、伯耆国、備後国、若狭国などの守護を歴任したほか官途奉行、引付頭人、評定衆等と室町幕府の重役を歴任した。
sen.e: With this success, he had held the position of Shugo (a military governor) of the Provinces of Hoki, Bingo, Wakasa, etc. as well as some main posts of the Muromachi Shogunate such as Kanto-bugyo (a commissioner to appoint officials to an office), Hikitsuke tonin (chairman of the court of justice) and hyojoshu (a member of the Council of State).

This success led him to serve as Shugo (a military governor) of Hoki, Bingo, and Wakasa Provinces as well as hold some main posts of the Muromachi Shogunate such as Kanto-bugyo (a commissioner of the appointment to an office), Hikitsuke tonin (chairman of the court of justice) and hyojosho (a member of the Council of State).

This success led him to serve as Shugo (a military governor) of Hoki, Bingo, and Wakasa Provinces as well as hold some main posts of the Muromachi Shogunate such as Kanto-bugyo (a commissioner of the appointment to an office), Hikitsuke tonin (chairman of the court of justice) and hyojosho (a member of the Council of State).

sen.j: しかし貞治2年（1363年）、再従兄弟である斯波高経と対立し、全役職をとかれて失脚してしまう。
sen.e: However, in 1363, he had an argument with his second cousin Takatsune SHIBA and lost all his posts.
However, in 1363, he had an argument with his second cousin Takatsune SHIBA and lost all his posts.
However, in 1363, he had an argument with his second cousin Takatsune SHIBA and lost all his posts.

sen.j: また、足利政権から正式に守護に選ばれたのは、一族で和義が最初であったが、在国一年程度では国人の被官化には繋がらずそれが、勢力を急速に落とした要因にも成っている。
sen.e: Although Kazuyoshi was the first in the clan to be appointed as a Shugo by the Ashikaga government, being in the position just for a year did not lead him to be made as a vassal of the Samurai family; this caused a rapid decline in the clan's power.

Kazuyoshi was the first clan member to be appointed as Shugo by the Ashikaga government, but one year service was not long enough to vassalize local lords, which fact partly resulted in his rapid decline.

Kazuyoshi was the first clan member to be appointed as Shugo by the Ashikaga government, but one year service was not long enough to vassalize local lords, which fact partly resulted in his rapid decline.

sen.j: 貞治5年（1366年）、斯波高経が失脚すると征夷大将軍足利義詮は和義の子石橋棟義を抜擢して奥州管領斯波直持と吉良貞経と協力して吉良治家を追討させた。
sen.e: In 1366, after Takatsune SHIBA's downfall, Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA selected Muneyoshi ISHIBASHI and ordered him to cooperate with the Oshu governor Tadamochi SHIBA and Sadatsune KIRA to search and kill Haruie KIRA.

In 1366, after Takatsune SHIBA's downfall, Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA ordered Muneyoshi ISHIBASHI, Kazuyoshi's son, to cooperate with the Oshu governor Tadamochi SHIBA and Sadatsune KIRA to search out and kill Haruie KIRA.

In 1366, after Takatsune SHIBA's downfall, Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA ordered Muneyoshi ISHIBASHI, Kazuyoshi's son, to cooperate with the Oshu governor Tadamochi SHIBA and Sadatsune KIRA to search out and kill Haruie KIRA.

sen.j: 棟義は治家を没落させた後も軍事指揮権を維持したまま、土着化する。
sen.e: After Haruie's fall, Muneyoshi held his post of military commander and settled in the area.
Even after Haruie's fall, Muneyoshi, as a military commander, settled in the area.
Even after Haruie's fall, Muneyoshi, as a military commander, settled in the area.

sen.j: さらに父和義も奥州に下向し、棟義の支配を助けた。
sen.e: His father Kazuyoshi also moved to Oshu and helped Muneyoshi's governance.
His father Kazuyoshi also moved to Oshu and helped Muneyoshi's governance.
His father Kazuyoshi also moved to Oshu and helped Muneyoshi's governance.

sen.j: 盛んに安堵状を発給し、その量は奥州管領斯波詮持をも凌駕した。
sen.e: They issued so many letters of ando (to secure property), the numbers of them overwhelmed the Oshu governor Akimochi SHIBA.
sen.cmt: 「その量は奥州管領斯波詮持をも凌駕した」の解釈に自信がありません。
sen.e: He issued so many letters of ando (certificate for land ownership), which outnumbered those issued by the Oshu governor Kiamichi SHEBA.
sen.cmt: ・表現の修正・この箇所は棟義がメインなので、棟義を主語としました。
sen.e: He issued so many letters of ando (certificate for land ownership), which outnumbered those issued by the Oshu governor Kiamichi SHEBA.

sen.j: しかし、至徳 (日本)3年（1386年）を境に消息が途絶える。
sen.e: However, what happened to them after 1386 is unknown.
However, nobody had heard anything about him since 1386.
sen.cmt: 棟義をメインとしました。
sen.e: However, nobody had heard anything about him since 1386.

sen.j: 塩松の伝承に拠れば、奥羽まで管轄下に置く事になった鎌倉公方・足利氏満によって1392年宇都宮氏が塩松に入部してきたが、反発する奥州探題・大崎詮持が1400年に葛西満信らと共に宇都宮氏を追討。
sen.e: According to the legend of Shionomatsu, when Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of the Kamakura region) Ujimitsu ASHIKAGA expanded his jurisdiction to the Ou region, one of the Utsunomiya clan moved to Shionomatsu in 1392; but rebellious Oshu Tandai (supervisors for the civil government and military affairs) Akimochi OZAKI killed Utsunomiya in 1400 with the help of Mitsunobu KASAI.

According to the legend of Shionomatsu, the Utsunomiya clan, dispatched by Ujimitsu ASHIKAGA, Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of the Kamakura region) who placed Ou under his jurisdiction, entered Shionomatsu in 1392, but rebellious Akimochi OSAKI, Oshu Tandai (supervisor for the civil government and military affairs in Oshu), in cooperation with Mitsunobu KASAI, searched out and killed the Utsunomiya clan in 1400.

According to the legend of Shionomatsu, the Utsunomiya clan, dispatched by Ujimitsu ASHIKAGA, Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of the Kamakura region) who placed Ou under his jurisdiction, entered Shionomatsu in 1392, but rebellious Akimochi OSAKI, Oshu Tandai (supervisor for the civil government and military affairs in Oshu), in cooperation with Mitsunobu KASAI, searched out and killed the Utsunomiya clan in 1400.

sen.j: 同氏が討った大崎氏は詮持の叔父・大崎持義を塩松持義として入部させる。
sen.e: After the Utsunomiya clan's revenge, the Osaki clan sent Akimochi's uncle Mochiyoshi OSAKI to Shionomatsu as Mochiyoshi SHIONOMATSU.
sen.cmt: 「同氏が討った大崎氏」部分の解釈に自信がありません。
sen.e: The Osaki clan which defeated the Utsunomiya clan dispatched Mochiyoshi OSAKI, Akimochi's uncle, to Shionomatsu as Mochiyoshi SHIONOMATSU.
sen.cmt: 「同氏が討った大崎氏」は「同氏（＝宇都宮氏）を討った大崎氏」でないと辻褄が合わないので、後者が正当と思われます。
sen.e: The Osaki clan which defeated the Utsunomiya clan dispatched Mochiyoshi OSAKI, Akimochi's uncle, to Shionomatsu as Mochiyoshi SHIONOMATSU.

sen.j: 数年後（十数年後とも）、持義も没してしまったため、同族に当たる石橋満博（棟義の子）が持義の女婿として入部したとされる。
sen.e: A few years later (it could have been a few decades), when Mochiyoshi died, from the same clan, Mitsuhiro ISHIBASHI (Muneyoshi's son) became Mochiyoshi's son-in-law and came to live in the area.

A few years later (or a few decades later according to some people), Mochiyoshi died and Mitsuhiro ISHIBASHI (Muneyoshi's son) who belonged to Mochiyoshi's family reportedly entered Shionomatsu as Mochiyoshi's son-in-law.

A few years later (or a few decades later according to some people), Mochiyoshi died and Mitsuhiro ISHIBASHI (Muneyoshi's son) who belonged to Mochiyoshi's family reportedly entered Shionomatsu as Mochiyoshi's son-in-law.

sen.j: その後正長・永享期には嫡流と思しき「石橋左衛門佐入道」が在京すると共に、正長元年（1428年）の『満済准后日記』に「奥篠河殿、並伊達蘆名白河懸田川俣塩松石橋也」と登場し、安達郡東方を分郡に塩松を名字とする庶流を分出していた。
sen.e: After that, in the Shoco and Eiko eras, a possible direct descendant called 'Saemon-no-suke-nyudo ISHIBASHI' was in Kyoto and in "Mansai Jugo Nikki" (dairy) mentioned '奥篠河殿、並伊達蘆名白河懸田川俣塩松石橋也'(Lord Sasagawa [Mitsunao ASHIKAGA] and Date, Ashina, Shirakawa, Kawamata, Shionomatsu and Ishibashi) and produced a branch family with Shionomatsu as its family name, having the eastern Adachi District as its territory.

After that, in the Shocho and Eikyo eras, a direct descendant called 'Saemon-no-suke-nyudo ISHIBASHI' was living in Kyoto, while, as "Mansai Jugo Nikki" (Mansai's diary) states '奥篠河殿、並伊達蘆名白河懸田川俣塩松石橋也' (Lord Sasagawa and Date, Ashina, Shirakawa, Kakeda, Kawamata, Shionomatsu, Ishibashi), a branch family of the Ishibashi clan surnamed Shionomatsu was living in eastern Adachi County.
sen.cmt: ・ある情報ソースによると、日記中の「塩松」＝石橋氏らしく、出典元を見ても該当の箇所は「石橋也」のみ斜字体になっています。しかし原文通りの処理をしました。http://www2.harimaya.com/sengoku/html/isibasi.html
sen.e: After that, in the Shocho and Eikyo eras, a direct descendant called 'Saemon-no-suke-nyudo ISHIBASHI' was living in Kyoto, while, as "Mansai Jugo Nikki" (Mansai's diary) states '奥篠河殿、並伊達蘆名白河懸田川俣塩松石橋也' (Lord Sasagawa and Date, Ashina, Shirakawa, Kakeda, Kawamata, Shionomatsu, Ishibashi), a branch family of the Ishibashi clan surnamed Shionomatsu was living in eastern Adachi County.

sen.j: こののちも、室町時代において吉良氏や渋川氏とともに、足利一門の名門 御一家として幕府内において一目置かれたが、最早守護大名衆の列からは完全に外された存在であった。
sen.e: The clan was recognized as a pedigree family of the Ashikaga family together with the Kira and Shibukawa clans in the Muromachi period, but they were no longer on the list of the Shugo Daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords).

In addition to the Kira and Shibukawa clans, the Ishibahshi clan was also recognized as a family of pedigree of the Ashikaga family in the Muromachi period, but there was no future for the clan as Shugo Daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords).

In addition to the Kira and Shibukawa clans, the Ishibahshi clan was also recognized as a family of pedigree of the Ashikaga family in the Muromachi period, but there was no future for the clan as Shugo Daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords).

sen.j: なお、戦国時代には、出雲国神門郡一窪田・吉野や石見国安濃郡太田北郷等に所領を持ちつつ、国人佐波氏の有力家人となり、雲州商人司に任ぜられた石橋氏の一族と思しき石橋源左衛門尉や石橋新左衛門尉が「島根石橋家」に登場する。
sen.e: In the Sengoku Period, having territory in Hitokubota, Kando District, Izumo Province and Yoshino as well as other places such as Otakitago, Ano District, Iwami Prefecture, the clan became influential retainers of the local lord Sawa clan; in the 'Shimane Ishibashi clan', there were Lieutenant Genzaemon ISHIBASHI, a possible descendant of the Ishibashi clan who was appointed as Shonintsukasa (privileged merchant) of Unshu (Izumo area), and Lieutenant Shizaemon ISHIBASHI.

In the Sengoku Period (period of warring states), having the territories in Hitokubota and Yoshino, Kando County, Izumo Province as well as in Otakitago, Ano County, Iwami Province, Genzaemon no jo ISHIBASHI and Shinzaemon no jo ISHIBASHI, possibly of the Ishibashi clan, both of whom became the influential retainers of the Sawa clan, a local lord, and were appointed as head of merchants of Unshu (= Izumo County), emerged from the Shimane Ishibashi clan.
sen.cmt: ・表現の修正・「国人・・・任ぜられた」が「石橋氏の一族」にかかるのか、「石橋源左衛門尉や石橋新左衛門尉」にかかるのか、分かりませんでした。一応両名がメインなので、後者に従いました。
sen.e: In the Sengoku Period (period of warring states), having the territories in Hitokubota and Yoshino, Kando County, Izumo Province as well as in Otakitago, Ano County, Iwami Province, Genzaemon no jo ISHIBASHI and Shinzaemon no jo ISHIBASHI, possibly of the Ishibashi clan, both of whom became the influential retainers of the Sawa clan, a local lord, and were appointed as head of merchants of Unshu (= Izumo County), emerged from the Shimane Ishibashi clan.

sen.j: 福岡県八女市の医師石橋正良宅に伝わる『石橋氏系図』によると、八女地方の石橋一族は、清和源氏の血を引く肥前出身の武士で豊後大友氏の門族である筑後国下田城主堤貞元の重臣石橋右衛門盛清（慶長6年没）が天正年間（1573年から1593年）に、筑後国生葉郡星野村に定住したのがはじまりである。
sen.e: According to the "Ishibashi Clan Family Tree" handed down to Dr Masayoshi ISHIBASHI of Yame City, Fukuoka Prefecture, the Ishibashi clan in the Yame region started when Uemon-morikiyo ISHIBASHI (died in 1601), a senior vassal of the lord of the Shimoda-jo Castle of the Chikugo Province Sadamoto TSUTSUMI who was a samurai from Hizen Province with the lineage of Seiwa-Genji and a family member of the Otomo clan of the Bungo Province, settled in Hoshino-mura village, Ikuha District, Chikugo Province in the Tensho era (1573 - 1593).
sen.cmt: 「石橋正良」、「堤貞元」は読みが不明です。
sen.e: According to the "Ishibashi Clan Family Tree" handed down to Dr 石橋正良 of Yame City, Fukuoka Prefecture, the Ishibashi clan in the Yame region started when Uemon-morikiyo ISHIBASHI (died in 1601), a senior vassal of the lord of the Shimoda-jo Castle of the Chikugo Province 堤貞元 who was a Seiwa Genji-lined samurai from Hizen Province and a family member of the Otomo clan of the Bungo Province, settled in Hoshino-mura village, Ikuha County, Chikugo Province in a certain point of the Tensho era (1573 - 1593).
sen.cmt: ・表現の修正・石橋正良と堤貞元は日本語表記に戻しました。
sen.e: According to the "Ishibashi Clan Family Tree" handed down to Dr 石橋正良 of Yame City, Fukuoka Prefecture, the Ishibashi clan in the Yame region started when Uemon-morikiyo ISHIBASHI (died in 1601), a senior vassal of the lord of the Shimoda-jo Castle of the Chikugo Province 堤貞元 who was a Seiwa Genji-lined samurai from Hizen Province and a family member of the Otomo clan of the Bungo Province, settled in Hoshino-mura village, Ikuha County, Chikugo Province in a certain point of the Tensho era (1573 - 1593).

sen.j: 医業は盛清の3代目にあたる作右衛門教清が寛永年間（1624年から1643年）に起こし、爾来、分家新立によって石橋医家の繁栄がもたらされた。
sen.e: Sakuemon, the third generation of Morikiyo started a medical practice during the Kanei era (1624 - 1643) and since then, with the new branch families' establishment, the doctor family of Ishibashi became successful.

Sakuemon Norikiyo, the third generation of Morikiyo started medical practice during the Kanei era (1624 - 1643) and since then, with the new branch families established, the Ishibashi became successful as a doctor family.
sen.cmt: 「教清」は「のりきよ」としました。
sen.e: Sakuemon Norikiyo, the third generation of Morikiyo started medical practice during the Kanei era (1624 - 1643) and since then, with the new branch families established, the Ishibashi became successful as a doctor family.

sen.j: 森鴎外との「舞姫論争」など、明治の文芸評論家として注目を集めた弁護士石橋忍月はこの流れを汲む。
sen.e: Lawyer Ningetsu ISHIBASHI, a high-profile literary critic of the Meiji period, who had the 'Maihime dispute' against Ogai MORI was a descendant of this clan.
Lawyer Ningetsu ISHIBASHI, a high-profile literary critic of the Meiji period, who had the 'Maihime dispute' against Ogai MORI was a descendant of this clan.
Lawyer Ningetsu ISHIBASHI, a high-profile literary critic of the Meiji period, who had the 'Maihime dispute' against Ogai MORI was a descendant of this clan.

sen.j: 石橋塩松氏
sen.e: Ishibashi-Shinomatsu Clan
The Ishibashi-Shionomatsu Clan
The Ishibashi-Shionomatsu Clan

sen.j: 石橋塩松氏は京都扶持衆として鎌倉府の奥州支配に対抗した。
sen.e: As a Kyoto-fuchishu (samurai with the direct master-servant relationship with the Seii Taishogun of the Muromachi Shogunate), the Ishibashi-Shionomatsu clan was opposed to the ruling of the Oshu region by the Kamakura Shogunate.
As Kyoto-fuchishu (a corps of special support troops in Kyoto), the Ishibashi Shionomatsu clan was opposed to the ruling of the Oshu region by the Kamakura-fu (Kamakura government)
As Kyoto-fuchishu (a corps of special support troops in Kyoto), the Ishibashi Shionomatsu clan was opposed to the ruling of the Oshu region by the Kamakura-fu (Kamakura government)

sen.j: 篠川御所足利満直は京都方であったので、京都との取次ぎ及び幕府の使者の宿泊は塩松氏が行っていた。
sen.e: The lord of the Sasagawa Palace Mitsunao ASHIKAGA was on the Kyoto side and the Shionomatsu clan's tasks were to deal with correspondence with the capital and organizing accommodation for the envoys from the Shogunate.

Because Mitsunao ASHIKAGA, head of Sasagawa Gosho (an administrative organization for governing Tohoku regions settled by the Kamakura bakufu in the Muromachi Period) was supporting the Kyoto side, the Shionomatsu clan acted as the liaison with Kyoto and arranged accommodation for envoys from the Shorgunate.

Because Mitsunao ASHIKAGA, head of Sasagawa Gosho (an administrative organization for governing Tohoku regions settled by the Kamakura bakufu in the Muromachi Period) was supporting the Kyoto side, the Shionomatsu clan acted as the liaison with Kyoto and arranged accommodation for envoys from the Shorgunate.

sen.j: 鎌倉府が永享の乱で崩壊した直後の永享12年（1440年）、篠川御所足利満直は畠山満泰、畠山持重、石橋左近将監、石橋祐義、蘆名盛信、田村利政らに攻められて殺害されたとの説もあるが石橋氏らの関与は疑問が呈されている（実際に篠川御所を弑したのは石川氏であろうと言われる）。
sen.e: There was a theory that, in 1440, straight after the downfall of the Kamakura Shogunate at the Eikyo War, the lord of the Sasagawa Palace Mitsunao ASHIKAGA was attacked and killed by Mitsuyasu HATAKEYAMA, Mochishige HATAKEYAMA, Sakon no shogen (Lieutenant the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) ISHIBASHI, Sukeyoshi ISHIBASHI, Morinobu ASHINA and Toshimasa TAMURA, etc,; but questions remain about the Ishibashi clan's involvement (in fact, it is said that it was the Ishikawa clan who killed the lord of the Sasakawa Palace).
sen.cmt: 「石橋祐義」、「田村利政」は読みが不明です。
sen.e: There was a theory that, in 1440, just after the downfall of the Kamakura government in the Eikyo War, Mitsunao ASHIKAGA (nicknamed Sasagawa Gosho) was attacked and killed by Mitsuyasu HATAKEYAMA, Mochishige HATAKEYAMA, Sakon no shogen ISHIBASHI, 石橋祐義, Morinobu ASHINA and Toshimasa TAMURA, etc, but questions remain about the Ishibashi clan's involvement (in fact, it is said that the Ishikawa clan killed Sasagawa Gosho).
sen.cmt: ・表現の修正・石橋祐義は日本語表記にしましたが、田村利政は翻訳以外に読みようがないので、そのままとしました。
sen.e: There was a theory that, in 1440, just after the downfall of the Kamakura government in the Eikyo War, Mitsunao ASHIKAGA (nicknamed Sasagawa Gosho) was attacked and killed by Mitsuyasu HATAKEYAMA, Mochishige HATAKEYAMA, Sakon no shogen ISHIBASHI, 石橋祐義, Morinobu ASHINA and Toshimasa TAMURA, etc, but questions remain about the Ishibashi clan's involvement (in fact, it is said that the Ishikawa clan killed Sasagawa Gosho).

sen.j: 何にせよ塩松氏は、篠川御所を廃した後、一地方国人としての道を選んだと考えられる。
sen.e: Whatever happened, the Shinomatsu clan were thought to have chosen to live as a local lord after killing the lord of the Sasakawa Palace.
It is possible that the Shionomatsu clan chose to live as a local lord after the demise of Sasagawa Gosho.
It is possible that the Shionomatsu clan chose to live as a local lord after the demise of Sasagawa Gosho.

sen.j: この頃の事は国人衆の記述が多い『余目氏旧記』にも出でこない事を考えると、足利一門として大崎氏や最上氏と同列に認識されていたと思われ、塩松氏（石橋氏）は高い家格を誇っていたこともわかる。
sen.e: Thinking that, what happened to the clan at that time was not written in the "Amarume shi Kyuki" (Old Record by the Amarume Clan) which had many details of powerful families in the Province, the clan was ranked in the same level as Osaki and Mogami clans as a family of the Ashikaga clan and the Shionomatsu (Ishibashi) clan was holding a high Kakaku (family status).

Because what happened to the clan at that time was not written in the "Amarume shi Kyuki" (Old Record by the Amarume Clan) which had many details of local lords, the clan, which was ranked in the same level as the Osaki and the Mogami clans as a family of the Ashikaga clan, boasted of high family status.

Because what happened to the clan at that time was not written in the "Amarume shi Kyuki" (Old Record by the Amarume Clan) which had many details of local lords, the clan, which was ranked in the same level as the Osaki and the Mogami clans as a family of the Ashikaga clan, boasted of high family status.

sen.j: 享徳の乱では石橋義仲という人物が奥州で活躍している。
sen.e: In the Kyotoku War, a person named Yoshinaka ISHIBASHI fought well in the Oshu region.
In the Kyotoku War, a person named Yoshinaka ISHIBASHI proved himself in Oshu.
In the Kyotoku War, a person named Yoshinaka ISHIBASHI proved himself in Oshu.

sen.j: 戦国時代に入り伊達氏の後継争いから生じた天文の乱では塩松尚義は伊達稙宗派として参戦したが、後に伊達晴宗派に鞍替えしている。
sen.e: When the Sengoku period began, in the Tenbun War which occurred from the succession race of the Date clan, Naoyoshi SHIONOMATSU fought for the Tanemune DATE's side but later on, changed to Harumune DATE's side.
sen.cmt: 「塩松尚義」は読みが不明です。
sen.e: In the Tenbun War, which occurred from the Date clan's succession race, during the Sengoku period, 塩松尚義 joined war on Tanemune DATE's side, but sided with Harumune DATE later.
sen.cmt: 塩松尚義は日本語表記に戻しました。
sen.e: In the Tenbun War, which occurred from the Date clan's succession race, during the Sengoku period, 塩松尚義 joined war on Tanemune DATE's side, but sided with Harumune DATE later.

sen.j: しかし、天文 (元号)19年（1550年）尚義は重臣の大内定頼に下克上され、城内に監禁され実権を奪われた。
sen.e: However, in 1550, due to the revolt of his senior vassal Sadayori OUCHI against him, Naoyoshi was held captive within the castle and lost his authority.
sen.cmt: 「大内定頼」の読みが不明です。
sen.e: However, in 1550, due to the revolt of his senior vassal Sadayori OUCHI against him, Naoyoshi was held captive within the castle and lost his authority.
However, in 1550, due to the revolt of his senior vassal Sadayori OUCHI against him, Naoyoshi was held captive within the castle and lost his authority.

sen.j: そして天正5年（1577年）に失意のうちに死亡したという。
sen.e: He is said to have died in 1755 in frustration.
He is said to have died in 1577 in frustration.
sen.cmt: 年号表記に誤りがありました。
sen.e: He is said to have died in 1577 in frustration.

sen.j: これにより石橋塩松氏は滅亡し、以降塩松氏というと大内氏のことをさすことになる。
sen.e: By this, the Ishibashi-Shionomatsu clan ended and the Shionomatsu clan after that means the Ouchi clan.
By this, the Ishibashi-Shionomatsu clan ended and the Shionomatsu clan after that meant the Ouchi clan.
sen.cmt: 最後の箇所は過去形にしました。
sen.e: By this, the Ishibashi-Shionomatsu clan ended and the Shionomatsu clan after that meant the Ouchi clan.
